characters: THE RIGHT MAN FOR THE JOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in the middle of the night, in the middle of nowhere. Small beams of light coming from lamps attached to the to cut through the ground mist. We HEAR all the unidentifiab sounds of night in the woods. We also HEAR, very, very  faintly, a slow, deliberate drum cadence. And as this sta we begin to MOVE SLOWLY UP THE TOWER, more becomes visibl now:... the sandbags on the ground piled ten-high... the  steel, fire escape-type stairway wrapping around the stru and leading to the lookout post, and finally... THE LOOKO POST, maybe forty feet off the ground. Standing the post is the silhouette of A MARINE. He's hol a rifle and staring straight out. The drum cadence has been building slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WIDER SHOT OF THE FENCELINE. And we see by the moonligh that the tall wire-mesh fence winds its way far, far into the distance. SUBTITLE: UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE GUANTANAMO BAY - CUBA. The drum cadence continues, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR two pairs of footsteps and then

dialogues.speaker: THE BARRACKS CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: where we see that the footsteps belong to DAWSON and DOWN two young marines who we'll get to know later. They stop  when they get to a certain door. The drum cadence is stil growing. DAWSON puts his hand on the doorknob and turns i slowly.  He opens's the door and they walk into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLY SANTIAGO, a young, very slight marine, lies asleep his bunk. DAWSON kneels down by the bed, puts his hand on SANTIAGO' shoulder and shakes him gently. SANTIAGO opens his yes, l at DAWSON, and for a moment there's nothing wrong -- -- and then SANTIAGO's eyes fill with terror. He lunges o of the bed -- but forget about it. In one flash DAWSON an DOWNEY grab him out of bed, and before the scream can com out, DOWNEY's shoved a piece of cloth into SANTIAGO's mou Everything that happens next occurs with speed, precision and professionalism. -- A strip of duct tape is pulled, ripped, and slapped on his mouth and eyes -- -- A length of rope is wrapped around his hands and feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're lucky it's us, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- An arm grabs him tightly around the neck, not choking  him, just holding his head still -- -- The drum cadence has built to a crescendo. We HEAR fou sharp blasts from a whistle and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and the drum cadence we've been hearing has turned into S Fidelis and it's coming from THE U.S. MARINE CORPS BAND, sight to behold in their red and gold uniforms and polish silver and brass. The BAND is performing on the huge and lush parade ground before a crowd made up mostly of TOURISTS and DAY-CAMPERS As the TITLES ROLL, we watch the BAND do their thing from various angles. Incredible precision is the name of the g Each polished black shoe hitting the ground as if they we all attached by a rod. Each drumstick raised to the same  fraction of a centimeter before striking. A RIFLE DRILL T that can't possibly be human. Flags, banners, the works. SUBTITLE: THE WASHINGTON NAVY YARD, WASHINGTON, D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE of the entire band an we end credits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an important building, a main building. A few SAILOR enter and exit and

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN
dialogues.text: as she walks across the courtyard toward the brick buildi The WOMAN is JOANNE GALLOWAY, a navy lawyer in her early  30's. She's bright, attractive, impulsive, and has a tend to speak quickly. If she had any friends, they'd call her JO. As she walks, she mutters to herself ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm requesting... I'm... Captain,  I'd like to request that I be the  attorney assigned to rep -- I'd like  to request that it be myself who is  assigned to represent -- (she stops) "That it be myself who is assigned  to represent"? ...Good, Jo, that's  confidence inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow JO, still muttering, as she walks into the bric building which bears the seal of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As JO  enters. CAPTAIN WEST and two other officers, GIBBS and LAWRENCE, sit around a conference table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain West, this is Lt. Commander  Galloway. Jo, you know Mike Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. (to WEST) Captain, I appreciate your seeing me  on such short notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand there was some trouble  over the weekend down in Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir... This past Friday evening.   Two marines, Corporal Harold Dawson  and Private Louden Downey, entered  the barracks room of a PFC William  Santiago and assaulted him. Santiago  died at the base hospital  approximately an hour later. The NIS  agent who took their statements  maintains they were trying to prevent  Santiago from naming them in a  fenceline shooting incident. They're  scheduled to have a hearing down in  Cuba at 4:00 this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson and Downey are both recruiting  poster marines and Santiago was known  to be a screw-up. I was thinking  that it sounded an awful lot like a  code red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo lets this sink in a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like them moved up to Washington  and assigned counsel. Someone who  can really look into this. Someone  who possesses not only the legal  skill, but a familiarity with the  inner workings of the military. In  short, Captain, I'd like to suggest  that... I be the one who, that it be  me who is assigned to represent them. (beat) Myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo looks around the room for a response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanne, why don't you get yourself a  cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanne, I'd like you to leave the  room so we can talk about you behind  your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO gets up and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this Code Red shit wasn't  going on anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the marines at GITMO? Who the  hell knows what goes on down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well lets find out before the rest  of the world does, this thing could  get messy. What about this woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo's been working a desk at internal  affairs for what, almost a year now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And before that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disposed of three cases in two  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three cases in two years? Who was  she handling, the Rosenbergs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not cut out for litigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a hall of an investigator,  Jerry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Internal Affairs, sure. She can  crawl up a lawyer's ass with the  best of 'em, but when it comes to  trial work --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. All passion, no street smarts.  Bring her back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAWRENCE goes to the door and motions for JO to come back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Commander, we're gonna move the  defendants up here in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll have Division assign them  counsel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) But... not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I understand from your  colleagues, you're much too valuable  in your present assignment to be  wasted on what I'm sure will boil  down to a five minute plea bargain  and a week's worth of paper work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. I promise you,  division'll assign the right man for  the job.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIGHT MAN FOR THE JOB
dialogues.text: His name is LIEUTENANT JUNIOR GRADE DANIEL ALLISTAIR KAFF and it's almost impossible not to like him. At the moment he's hitting fungoes to about a dozen LAWYERS who are spr out on the softball field on a corner of the bass. The '2 Yankees they're not, but they could probably hold their o against a group of, say, Airforce dentists. KAFFEE's in his late 20's, 15 months out of Harvard Law  School, and a brilliant legal mind waiting for a courageo spirit to drive it. He is, at this point in his life,  passionate about nothing... except maybe softball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out to the  team) Alright, let's get two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smacks one to the SECOND BASE. The ball bounces right  between his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to be sorry about, Sherby.   Just look the ball into your glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smacks one out to the same place. It bounces off the h of SHERBY's glove and into center field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta trust me, Sherby. You keep  your eyes open, your chances of  catching the ball increase by a factor  of ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPRADLING, a young naval officer, sweaty and out of breat walks up behind the backstop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaffee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaffee!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) Dave. You seem upset and distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were supposed to meet in your  office 15 minutes ago to talk about  the McDermott case. You're stalling  on this thing. Now we got this done  and I mean now, or no kidding, Kaffee,  I'll hang your boy from a fuckin'  yardarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A yardarm? (calling out) Sherby, does the Navy still hang  people from yardarms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back) I don't think so, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to SPRADLING) Dave, Sherby doesn't think the Navy  hangs people from yardarms anymore. (back to the field) Let's go, let's get two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to hitting fungoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna charge him with possession  and being under the influence while  on duty. Plead guilty and I'll  recommend 30 days in the brig with  loss of rank and pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was oregano, Dave, it was ten  dollars worth of oregano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well your client thought it  was marijuana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My client's a moron, that's not  against the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swapp! The THIRD BASEMAN takes one in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Ow. That had to hurt. (calling out) Way to keep your head in the play,  Lester. Walk it off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got people to answer to just  like you, I'm gonna charge him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what, possession of a condiment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaffee --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, I've tried to help you out of  this, but if you ask for tall time,  I'm gonna file a motion to dismiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will get it. And if the MTD is  denied, I'll file a motion in liminee  seeking to obtain evidentiary ruling  in advance, and after that I'm gonna  file against pre-trial confinement,  and you're gonna spend an entire  summer going blind on paperwork  because a Signalman Second Class  bought and smoked a dime bag of  oregano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B Misdemeanor, 20 days in the brig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C Misdemeanor, 15 days restricted  duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I'm agreeing to  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you have wisdom beyond your  years. Dave, can you play third base?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 16 NAVY AND MARINE LAWYERS (several of whom are wom are taking their seats around a large conference table. A PARALEGAL is handing out folders and some photocopied p to the LAWYERS. We might notice that one of the lawyers is Lieutenant Jun Grade SAM WEINBERG. Sam's serious and studious looking. I he weren't in uniform, you wouldn't guess that he was a n officer. CAPTAIN WHITAKER walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (school class) 'Morning Captain Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, how's the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's ready to say her first  word any day now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just looks like she has something  to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you don't have a good excuse,  so I won't force you to come up with  a bad one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Isaac, that's nice of  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit-down, this first one's for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands KAFFEE some files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're moving up in the world, Danny,  you've been requested by Division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oooh"'s and "Ahhh"'S from the other LAWYERS. (Subtle Not Kaffee doesn't want to move up in the world.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Requested to do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITAKER hands him a file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. A marine  corporal named Dawson illegally fires  a round from his weapon over the  fenceline and into Cuban territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a fenceline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big wall separating the good guys  from the bad guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teachers pet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PFC William Santiago threatens to  rat on Dawson to the Naval  investigative Service. Dawson and  another member of his squad, PFC  Louden Downey, they go into Santiago's  room, tie him up, and stuff a rag  down his throat. An hour later,  Santiago's dead. Attending physician  says the rag was treated with some  kind of toxin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They poisoned the rag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not according to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. They're being flown up  here tomorrow and on Thursday at  0600 you'll catch a transport down  to Cuba for the day to find out what  you can. Meantime, go across the  yard and see Lt. Commander Joanne  Galloway. She's the one who had 'em  brought up here. She'll fill you in  on whatever she has. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight to Cuba, was that 0600 in  the morning, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems important to Division that  this one be handled by the book, so  I'm assigning co-counsel. Any  volunteers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a stack of paper on my desk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work with Kaffee on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing what? Kaffee'll finish this up  in four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do various... administrative... you  know... things. Back-up. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words I have no  responsibilities whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My kinda case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO sits behind her desk. KAFFEE and SAM stand in the door KAFFEE knocks politely. JO looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. (beat) I'm Daniel Kaffee. I was told to  meet with -- (checks notes) -- Commander Galloway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO is staring at him. KAFFEE doesn't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) About a briefing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO is finding this hard to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the attorney that Division  assigned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lead counsel. This is Sam  Weinberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no responsibilities here  whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO's deeply puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Come in, please, have a seat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE and SAM come into the office and sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Lieutenant, how long have you been  in the Navy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going on nine months now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how long have you been out of  law school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little over a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I done something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's just that when I petitioned  Division to have counsel assigned, I  was hoping I'd be taken seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE and SAM exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JO) No offense taken, if you were  wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, Lt. Kaffee's generally  considered the best litigator in our  office. He's successfully plea  bargained 44 cases in nine months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more, and I got a set of steak  knives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been in a courtroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once had my drivers license  suspended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, from what I understand,  if this thing goes to court, they  won't need a lawyer, they'll need a  priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They'll need a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, she'll hand KAFFEE a series of files, which  KAFFEE will pass To SAM without even glancing at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Dawson's family has been contacted.   Downey's closest living relative is  Ginny Miller, his aunt on his mother's  side, she hasn't been Contacted yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of this really means anything to KAFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Would you like me to take care of  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, if you feel like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO takes another beat to size this guy up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the people you'll be speaking  to down there is the barracks C.O.,  Colonel Nathan Jessep, I assume you've  heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Who hasn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to KAFFEE) He's been in the papers lately. He's  expected to be appointed Director of  Operations for the National Security  Counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing KAFFEE another file --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are letters that Santiago wrote  in his 8 months at GITMO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to kaffee) Guantanamo Bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrote to his recruiter, the fleet  commander, HQ, Atlantic, even his  senator. He wanted a transfer. Nobody  was listening. You with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This last letter to the Naval  investigative Service --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands it to KAFFEE who hands it to Sam --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) -- where he offers information about  Corporal Dawson's fenceline shooting  in exchange for a transfer, was just  a last ditch effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Lieutenant, this letter makes it  look like your client had a motive  to kill Santiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha. (beat) And Santiago is... who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) The victim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SAM) Write that down. (to JO) Am I correct in assuming that these  letters don't paint a flattering  picture of marine corps life in  Guantanamo Bay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, among other --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And am I further right in assuming  that a protracted investigation of  this incident might cause some  embarrassment for the security counsel  guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Jessep, yes, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve years. I can get it knocked  down to Involuntary Manslaughter.  Twelve years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't talked to a witness, you  haven't looked at a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty impressive, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to go deeper than  just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, do you have some sort of  jurisdiction here that I should know  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job is to make sure you do your  job. I'm special counsel for Internal  Affairs, so my jurisdiction's pretty  much in your face. Read the letters.  You're not under any obligation, but  I'd appreciate a report when you get  back from Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE gets up without waiting for JO to say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I always forget that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE's gone. SAM's standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a little preoccupied. (beat) The team's playing Bethesda Medical  next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell your friend not to get cute  down there.  The marines in Guantanimo  are fanatical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in VOICE OVER we HEAR --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Sir,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About being marines.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: And while we HEAR the letter read in V.O., what we're see is this: SANTIAGO's life in Guantanimo Bay over the last months. He had a rough time of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- SANTIAGO running along at the rear of a group of MARIN It's been over seven miles and he's matted with sweat. A  SERGEANT runs up along side, grabs his back, and pushes h to keep up with the group. SANTIAGO falls, struggles to g back up and keep running, and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- SANTIAGO doing push-ups alone in the rain. He's being  supervised by a SERGEANT who sees to it that his face hit the mud every time down and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- SANTIAGO sitting alone in the mess hall, not a friend  within four seats of him and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- SANTIAGO being chewed out by a Lieutenant in front of squad and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- SANTIAGO running with the squad of MARINES again, this time down a rocky hill. It's hot as hell and it looks lik he's gonna pass out. He stumbles, and the SERGEANT picks him up and pushes him down the hill. He rolls about 30 feet before he stops. Ov this, we HEAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...My name is PFC William T.  Santiago. I am a marine stationed at  Marine Barracks, Rifle Security  Company Windward, Second Platoon  Delta. I am writing to inform you of  my problems with my unit here in  Cuba and to ask for your help. I've  fallen out on runs before for several  reasons such as feeling dizzy or  nauseated, but on May 18th, I'd fallen  back about 20 or 30 yards going down  a rocky, unstable hill. My sergeant  grabbed me and pushed me down the  hill. Then I saw all black and the  last thing I remember is hitting the  deck. I was brought to the hospital  where I was told I just had heat  exhaustion and was explained to by  the doctor that my body has trouble  with the hot sun and I hyperventilate.  I ask you to help me. Please sir. I  just need to be transferred out of  RSC. Sincerely. PFC William T.  Santiago. U.S. Marine Corps."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point, with SANTIAGO's letter still in V.O., we

dialogues.speaker: THE LETTER
dialogues.text: It's the last paragraph of the letter we've been hearing, and at the moment, we can't see the hands that are holdin it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "P.S. In exchange for my transfer  off the base, I'm willing to provide  you with information about an illegal  fenceline shooting that occurred the  night of August 2nd."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as these last words are spoken, we PULL BACK TO REVEA COLONEL NATHAN R. JESSEP, who drops the letter he's been  reading on his desk, where it joins a stack of other lett just like it. JESSEP's a born leader, considered in many circles to be of the real fair-haired boys of the Corps. He's smart as whip with a sense of humor to match. As soon as he drops letter, he says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck is PFC William T.  Santiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's talking to his two senior officers. CAPTAIN MARKINSO is in his late 40's. He's a career marine and a nice guy a world where nice guys may not finish last, but they sur as shit don't finish first. Lt. JONATHAN JAMES KENDRICK i 26, from Georgia, and an Academy graduate. If you asked him he'd tell you that the gates to heaven a guarded by the U.S. Marine Corps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Santiago is a member of Second  Platoon, Delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, apparently he's not very  happy down here at Shangri-La, cause  he's written letters to everyone but  Santa Claus asking for a transfer.  And now he's telling tales about a  fenceline shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the letter over to MARKINSON. MARKINSON is look it over. JESSEP is waiting for a response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Matthew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm appalled, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're appalled? This kid broke the  Chain of Command and he ratted on a  man of his unit, to say nothing of  the fact that he's a U.S. Marine and  it would appear that he can't run  from here to there without collapsing  from heat exhaustion. What the fuck's  going on over at Windward, Matthew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I think perhaps it would be  better to hold this discussion in  private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary, Colonel,  I'll handle the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same way you handled the Curtis  Barnes incident? You're doing  something wrong, Lieutenant this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My methods of leadership are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't interrupt me, I'm still your  superior officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm yours, Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room calms down for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I want to know what we're gonna do  about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Santiago should be transferred  off the base. Right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's that bad, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only that, but word of this  letter's bound to get out. The kid's  gonna get his ass kicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transfer Santiago. Yes I suppose  you're right. I suppose that's the  thing to do. Wait. Wait. I've got a  better idea. Let's transfer the whole  squad off the base. Let's -- on second  thought -- Windward. The whole  Windward division, let's transfer  'em off the base. Jon, go on out  there and get those boys down off  the fence, they're packing their  bags. (calling out) Tom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ORDERLY cones in from the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got me the President on the phone,  we're surrendering our position in  Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ORDERLY stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't call the President just yet.  Maybe we should consider this for a  second. Maybe -- and I'm just spit  balling here -- but maybe we as  officers have a responsibility to  train Santiago. Maybe we as officers  have a responsibility to this country  to see that the men and women charged  with its security are trained  professionals. Yes. I'm certain I  once read that somewhere. And now  I'm thinking that your suggestion of  transferring Santiago, while  expeditious, and certainly painless,  might not be in a manner of speaking,  the American way. Santiago stays  where he is. We're gonna train the  lad. You're in charge, Jon. Santiago  doesn't make 4.1 on his next fitness  report, I'm gonna blame you. Then  I'm gonna kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's a mistake, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew, I believe I will have that  word in private with you now. Jon,  that's all. Why don't you and I have  lunch at the "O" club, we'll talk  about the training of young William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, I'd be delighted to hear  any suggestions you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KENDRICK is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Matthew, sit, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARKINSON sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What do you think of Kendrick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I don't know that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's kind of a weasel, myself.  But he's an awfully good officer,  and in the end we see eye to eye on  the best way to run a marine corps  unit. We're in the business of saving  lives, Matthew. That's a  responsibility we have to take pretty  seriously. And I believe that taking  a marine who's not yet up to the job  and packing him off to another  assignment, puts lives in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARKINSON starts to stand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Matthew, siddown. (beat) We go back a while. We went to the  Academy together, we were commissioned  together, we did our tours in Vietnam  together. But I've been promoted up  through the chain with greater speed  and success than you have. Now if  that's a source of tension or  embarrassment for you, well, I don't  give a shit. We're in the business  of saving lives, Captain Markinson.  Don't ever question my orders in  front of another officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSEP grabs his hat and walks out, leaving MARKINSON sit all alone, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's maybe a little hazier today than it was yesterday. A M.P. is waving a procession of three Military Police seda and a fourth unmarked car through the gate. The cars driv through and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another red-brick building. A few M.P.Is stand out front the cars pull up. As soon as they come to a stop, all the doors swing open and various uniformed and non-uniformed  officers hop out and move to the unmarked sedan where the escort DAWSON and DOWNEY, in handcuffs, out of the car.   HAROLD DAWSON's a handsome, young, black corporal. Intens controlled, and utterly professional. LOUDEN DOWNEY's a 19-year-old kid off an Iowa farm. He's  happiest when someone is telling him exactly what to do. DAWSON's his hero. The two prisoners stand still for a moment. They might as we'll be in Oz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Is this Washington, D.C.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, let's move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and KAFFEE's at it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, let's get tough out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO walks up from behind the backstop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to suit up? We need all the  help we can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you, I can't throw and  catch things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, neither can they.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you about Corporal  Dawson and Private Downey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson and Downey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Those names sound like they should  mean something to me, but I'm just  not --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson! Downey! Your clients!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cuba thing! Yes! Dawson and  Downey. (beat) Right. (pause) I've done something wrong again,  haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering why two guys have  been in a jail cell since this morning  while their lawyer is outside hitting  a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need the practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a little funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, would you feel very  insulted if I recommended to your  supervisor that he assign different  counsel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you're fit to handle  this defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know me. Ordinarily  it takes someone hours to discover  I'm not fit to handle a defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo just stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh come on, that was damn funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo moves close to KAFFEE to say this with a degree of  confidentiality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do know you. Daniel AlliStair  Kaffee, born June 8th, 1964 at Boston  Mercy Hospital. Your father's Lionel  Kaffee, former Navy Judge Advocate  and Attorney General, of the United  States, died 1985. You went to Harvard  Law on a Navy scholarship, probably  because that's what your father wanted  you to do, and now you're just  treading water for the three years  you've gotta serve in the JAG Corps,  just kinda layin' low til you can  get out and get a real job. And if  that's the situation, that's fine, I  won't tell anyone. But my feeling is  that if this case is handled in the  same fast-food, slick-ass, Persian  Bazaar manner with which you seem to  handle everything else, something's  gonna get missed. And I wouldn't be  doing my job if I allowed Dawson and  Downey to spend any more time in  prison than absolutely necessary,  because their attorney had pre- determined the path of least  resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE can't help but be impressed by that speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. (beat) I'm sexually aroused, Commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think your clients murdered  anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you basing this on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor's report says that Santiago  died of asphyxiation brought on by  acute lactic acidosis, and that the  nature of the acidosis strongly  suggests poisoning. (beat) Now, I don't know what any of that  means, but it sounds pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago died at one a.m. At three  the doctor was unable to determine  the cause of death, but two hours  later he said it was poison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now I see what you're saying.   It had to be Professor Plum in the  library with the candlestick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna speak to your supervisor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. You go straight up Pennsylvania  Avenue. It's a big white house with  pillars in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you'll have much luck,  though. I was assigned by Division,  remember? Somebody over there thinks  I'm a good lawyer. So while I  appreciate your interest and admire  your enthusiasm, I think I can pretty  much handle things myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what a code red is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE doesn't, but he doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What a pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And an M.P. is leading KAFFEE and SAM down to DAWSON and  DOWNEY's cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer on deck, ten-hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON and DOWNEY come to attention. Through the followin the M.P. will unlock the call door and let the lawyers in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Lance Corporal Harold W. Dawson,  sir. Rifle Security Company Windward,  Second Platoon, Delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone hasn't been working and  playing well with others, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, yes sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, PFC Louden Downey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Daniel Kaffee, this is Sam  Weinerg, you can sitdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON and DOWNEY aren't too comfortable sitting in the  presence of officers, but they do as they're told. KAFFEE pulled out some documents, SAM's sitting on one of the co taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to DAWSON) Is this your signature?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to call me sir. (to DOWNEY) Is this your signature?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you certainly don't have to do  it twice in one sentence. Harold,  what's a Code Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, a Code Red is a disciplinary  engagement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, a marine falls out of line,  it's up to the men in his unit to  get him back on track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a garden variety Code Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, you say sir and I turn around  and look for my father. Danny, Daniel,  Kaffee. Garden variety; typical.  What's a basic Code Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, a marine has refused to bathe  on a regular basis. The men in his  squad would give him a G.I. shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrub brushes, brillo pads, steel  wool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the attack on Santiago a Code  Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DOWNEY) Do you ever talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Private Downey will answer any  direct questions you ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell. Private Downey, the rag you  stuffed in Santiago's mouth, was  there poison on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silver polish, turpentine, anti- freeze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. We were gonna shave his head,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When all of a sudden...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw blood drippinq out of his  mouth. Then we pulled the tape off,  and there was blood all down his  face, sir. That's when Corporal Dawson  called the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE tries not to make too big a deal out of this last  piece of news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DAWSON) Did anyone see you call the ambulance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you there when the ambulance  got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, that's when we were taken  under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE kinda strolls to the corner of the cell to think f a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DAWSON) On the night of August 2nd, did you  fire a shot across the fenceline  into Cuba?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mirror engaged, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SAM) His mirror engaged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For each American sentry post there's  a Cuban counterpart. They're called  mirrors. The corporal's claiming  that his mirror was about to fire at  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago's letter to the NIS said  you fired illegally. He's saying  that the guy, the mirror, he never  made a move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM is staring at DAWSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You see what I'm getting at? If  Santiago didn't have anything on  you, then why did you give him a  Code Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he broke the chain of command,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went outside his unit, sir. If he  had a problem, he should've spoken  to me, sir. Then his Sergeant, then  Company Commander, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, alright. Harold, did you  assault Santiago with the intent of  killing him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your intent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To train him, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Train him to do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Train him to think of his unit before  himself. To respect the code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the code?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unit Corps God Country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unit Corps God Country, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Goverrment of the United States  wants to charge you two with murder.  You want me to go to the prosecutor  with unit, corps, god, country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON stares at KAFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's our code, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE takes a long moment. He picks up his briefcase and and SAM move to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be back. You guys need anything?  Books paper, cigarettes, a ham  sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. No thank you. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE smiles at DAWSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, I think there's a concept  you better start warming up to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the only friend you've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as KAFFEE and SAM walk out the open cell door, DAWSON and DOWNEY come to attention and snap a salute. They hold the salute until KAFFEE and SAM are well out of sight, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's packing up stuff into his briefcase at the end of th work day. Lt. JACK ROSS, a marine lawyer maybe two years  older than Kaffee, opens the door and walks in..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Kaffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sailin' Jack Ross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the big time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope for Dawson and Downey's sake  you practice law better than you  play softball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately for Dawson and Downey,  I don't do anything better than I  play softball. What are we lookin'  at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They plead guilty to manslaughter,  I'll drop the conspiracy and the  conduct unbecoming. 20 years, they'll  be home in half that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They called the ambulance, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if they called the Avon  Lady, they killed a marine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rag was tested for poison.  The  autopsy, lab report, even the initial  E.R. and C.O.D. reports. They all  say the same thing: Maybe, maybe  not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief of Internal Medicine at  the Guantanamo Bay Naval hospital  says he's sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about Code Reds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are we off the record?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I'm gonna give you the twelve years,  but before you go getting yourself  into trouble tomorrow, you should  know this: The platoon commander Lt.  Jonathan Kendrick, had a meeting  with the men. And he specifically  told them not to touch Santiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE holds for a moment. Dawson and Downey neglected to mention this... He packs up his briefcase and cleats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to you when I get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we got a little four-on-four  going tomorrow night. When does your  plane get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dusk and people on the base are going home from work We can see the flag being lowered in the background. KAFFEE's walking toward his car. JO intercepts him and st walking along with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any luck getting me replaced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anyone in this command that  you don't either drink or play  softball with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I came to make peace. We  started off on the wrong foot. What  do you say? Friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I brought Downey some  comic books he was asking for. The  kid, Kaffee, I swear, he doesn't  know where he is, he doesn't even  know why he's been arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can call me Joanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanne --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: or Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, if you ever speak to a client of  mine again without my permission,  I'll have you disbarred. Friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had authorization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downey's closest living relative,  Ginny Miller, his aunt on his mother's  side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got authorization from Aunt Ginny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave her a call like you asked.  Very nice woman, we talked for about  an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got authorization from Aunt Ginny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly within my province.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Aunt Ginny have a barn? We can  hold the trial there. I can sew the  costumes, and maybe his Uncle Goober  can be the judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo steps aside and lets KAFFEE got into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Cuba with you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the hits just keep on comin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on KAFFEE and Jo. JO smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KAFFEE IN HIS CAR
dialogues.text: He's driving down a Washington street and pulls over at a sidewalk newsstand. He gets out of his car, leaving the lights flashing, and  runs up to the newsstand. As he plunks his 35 cents down and picks up a newspaper, engages in his daily ritual with LUTHER, the newsstand  operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin', Luther?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day, another dollar, captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta play 'em as they lay,  Luther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What comes around, goes around, you  know what I'm sayin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't beat 'em, join 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if you've got your health, you  got everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love makes the world go round. I'll  see you tomorrow, Luther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baby sleeping in a crib pull rack to reveal SAM is stan over the crib. KAFFEE's sitting on a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Nancy gets back, you're my  witness. The baby spoke. My daughter  said a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter made a sound, Sam, I'm  not sure it was a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, it was a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard her. The girl sat here,  pointed, and said "Pa". She did. She  said "Pa".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was pointing at a doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Pointing, as if to  say, "Pa, look, a doorknob".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM joins KAFFEE in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Ross came to see me today. He  offered me twelve years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, and I'll... I guess, I mean -- (beat) I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took albout 45 seconds. He barely  put up a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Danny, take the twelve years, it's a  gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE finishes off his beer, and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe their story, do  you? You think they ought to go to  jail for the rest of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe every word they said. And  I think they ought to go to jail for  the rest of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE nods and puts down the empty beer bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam opens the front door for him and they stand out on th stoop for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember to wear your whites, it's  hot down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the whites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody likes the whites, but we're  going to Cuba in August. You got  Dramamine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dramamine keeps you cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dramamine keeps you from throwing  up, you get sick when you fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get sick when I fly because I'm  afraid of crashing into a large  mountain, I don't think Dramamine'll  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some oregano, I hear that  works pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE starts toward his car, then turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know, Ross said the strangest  thing to me right before I left. He  said the platoon commander Lieutenant  Jonathan Kendrick had a meeting with  the men and specifically told them  not to touch Santiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never mentioned Kendrick. I don't  even know who he is. (beat) What the hell. (beat) I'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hold for a moment on KAFFEE as he walks to his car, th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole place, in stark contrast to the Washington Navy Yard, is ready to go to war. Fighter jets line the tarmac Ground crews re-fuel planes. Hurried activity. A 36 seat Airforce Jet rolls to a stop on the tarmac and stair unit is brought up. HOWARD, a marine corporal, is waiting by the stairway as passengers begin to got off. Mostly MARINES, a few SAILOR a couple of CIVILIANS, and KAFFEE, JO and SAM. KAFFEE and SAM are wearing their summer whites, JO is in khakis. KAFFEE and SAM stare out at what they see: They're not in Kansas anymore. HOWARD shouts over the noise from the planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenants Kaffee and Weinberg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander Galloway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Corporal Howard, ma'am, I'm to  escort you to the Windward side of  the base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some camouflage jackets in  the back of the jeep, sirs, I'll  have to ask you both to put them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camouflage jackets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regulations, sir. We'll be riding  pretty close to the fenceline. The  Cubans see an officer wearing white,  they think it's someone they might  wanna take a shot at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE turns and glares at SAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good call, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tearing along down the road, and now we see a beautiful  expanse of water, maybe 1000 yards across. It's a section Guantanamo Bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) We'll just hop on the ferry and be  over there in no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Whoa! Hold it! We gotta take a boat?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, to get to the other side of  the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody said anything about a boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Is there a problem, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) No. No problem. I'm just not that  crazy about boats, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Jesus Christ, Kaffee, you're in the  Navy for cryin' out loud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Nobody likes her very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jeep drives on and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSEP, MARKINSON and KENDRICK are standing as the LAWYER are led in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan Jessep, come on in and siddown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm Daniel Kaffee, I'm  the attorney for Dawson and Downey.  This is Joanne Galloway, she's  observing and evaluating --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, Commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Weinberg. He has no responsibility  here whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked Captain Markinson and Lt.   Kendrick to join us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kaffee, I had the pleasure of  seeing your father once. I was a  teenager and he spoke at my high  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel Kaffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what do you know. Son, this  man's dad once made a lot of enemies  down in your neck of the woods.  Jefferson vs. Madison County School  District. The folks down there said  a little black girl couldn't go to  an all white school, Lionel Kaffee  said we'll just see about that. How  the hell is your dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passed away seven years ago,  colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Well... don't I feel like the fuckin,  asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what can we do for you, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much at all, sir, I'm afraid.  This is really a formality more than  anything else. The JAG Corps insists  that I interview all the relevant  witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JAG Corps can be demanding that  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSEP smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonanthan'll take you out and show  you what you wanna see, then we can  all hook up for lunch, how does that  sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SQUAD OF MARINES jogs by as a jeep carrying KENDRICK an the three LAWYERS cruises down the road. We FOLLOW the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you had a meeting with  your men that afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you guys talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the men that there was an  informer among us. And that despite  any desire they might have to seek  retribution, Private Santiago was  not to be harmed in any way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time was that meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen-hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE turns around and looks at SAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) Four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KENDRICK leads the LAWYERS down the corridor to Santiago' room. Two strips of tape which warn DO NOT ENTER - AT ORDER OF MILITARY POLICE are crisscrossed over the closed door. Th open the door and step under the tape and walk into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is exactly an it was left that night. The un-mad bed, the chair knocked over... The LAWYERS look around fo moment. The room is sparse. Kaffee goes to the closet and opens it: A row of uniforms hanging neatly. He thumbs through then for a second, but  there's nothing there. He opens the footlocker: Socks, underwear... all folded t marine corp precision... A shaving kit, a couple of  photographs, a pad of writing paper and some envelopes... Kaffee closes the footlocker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, somebody should see about getting  this stuff to his parents. We don't  need it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, the uniforms belong to the  marine corps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LAWYERS take a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick -- can I call you Jon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you may not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Have I done something to offend you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I like all you Navy boys. Every  time we've gotta go someplace and  fight, you fellas always give us a  ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick, do you think Santiago  was murdered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, I believe in God, and in  his son Jesus Christ, and because I  do, I can say this: Private Santiago  is dead and that's a tragedy. But  he's dead because he had no code.  He's dead because he had no honor.  And God was watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM turns to KAFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel about that theory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Sounds good. Let's move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM and KENDRICK walk out the door. JO stops KAFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You planning on doing any  investigating or are you just gonna  take the guided tour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I'm pacing myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSEP, MARKINSON, KENDRICK and the LAWYERS are seated at table in the corner. Stewards clear the lunch dishes and pour coffee. Jessep i finishing a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And they spent the next three  hours running around, looking for  Americans to surrender to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSEP laughs. KENDRICK joins him. SAM and KAFFEE force a laugh. MARKINSON forces a smile. JO remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to the  STEWARDS) That was delicious, men, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our pleasure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel just need to ask you a couple  of questions about August 6th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the morning of the sixth, you  were contacted by an NIS angent who  said that Santiago had tipped him  off to an illegal fenceline shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago was gonna reveal the person's  name in exchange for a transfer. An  I getting this right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you feel there are any details  that I'm missing, you should free to  speak up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSEP's not quite sure what to say to this Navy Lawyer  Lieutenant-Smartass guy who just gave him permission to s freely on his own base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it was at this point that you  called Captain Markinson and Lt.  Kendrick into your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We agreed that for his own safety,  Santiago should be transferred off  the base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's something else KAFFEE didn't know. Neither did Jo. SAM jots something down on a small notepad. MARKINSON doesn't flinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago was set to be transferred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the first available flight to the  states. Six the next morning. Three  hours too late as it turned out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's silence for a moment. KAFFEE takes a sip of his coffee. Then drains the cup and puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Alright, that's all I have. Thanks  very much for your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corporal's got the jeep outside,  he'll take you back to the airstrip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, I've got some  questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, on the morning that Santiago  died, did you meet with Doctor Stone  between three and five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I met with the doctor. One  of my men was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JO) See? The man was dead. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JESSEP) I was wondering if you've ever heard  the term Code Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard the term, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, this past February, you  received a cautionary memo from the  Naval Investigative Service, warning  that the practice of enlisted men  disciplining their own wasn't to be  condoned by officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I submit to you that whoever wrote  that memo has never served on the  working end of a Soviet-made Cuban  Ml-Al6 Assault Rifle. However, the  directive having come from the NIS,  I gave it its due attention. What's  your point, Jo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has no point. She often has no  point. It's part of her charm. We're  outta here. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My point is that I think code reds  still go on down here. Do Code Reds  still happen on this base, colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, the colonel doesn't need to answer  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he really doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he really does. Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it just hit me. She outranks  you, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to tell you something Danny  and listen up 'cause I mean this:  You're the luckiest man in the world.  There is, believe me gentlemen,  nothing sexier on earth than a woman  you have to salute in the morning.  Promote 'em all I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO's not upset. JO's not mad. But she's gonna ask her que 'til she gets an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, the practice of code Reds  is still condoned by officers on  this base, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see my problem is, of course,  that I'm a Colonel. I'll just have  to keep taking cold showers 'til  they elect some gal President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need an answer to my question,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take caution in your tone, Commander.   I'm a fair guy, but this fuckin'  heat's making me absolutely crazy.  You want to know about code reds?   On the record I tell you that I  discourage the practice in accordance  with the NIS directive. Off the record  I tell you that it's an invaluable  part of close infantry training, and  if it happens to go on without my  knowledge, so be it. I run my base  how I run my base. You want to  investigate me, roll the dice and  take your chances. I eat breakfast  80 yards away from 4000 Cubans who  are trained to kill me. So don't for  one second think you're gonna come  down here, flash a badge, and make  me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of tense silence before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. Colonel, I'll just need a  copy of Santiago's transfer order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago's transfer order. You guys  have paper work on that kind of thing,  I just need it for the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Of course you can have a copy of the  transfer order. For the file. I'm  here to help anyway I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that, don't you? Danny?  That I'm here to help anyway I can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corporal'll run you by Ordinance  on your way out to the airstrip. You  can have all the transfer orders you  want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JO and SAM) Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LAWYERS start to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have to ask me nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE stops. Turns around. Sam and JO stop and turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to ask me nicely. You see,  Danny, I can deal with the bullets  and the bombs and the blood. I can  deal with the heat and the stress  and the fear. I don't want money and  I don't want medals. What I want is  for you to stand there in that faggoty  white uniform, and with your Harvard  mouth, extend me some fuckin'  courtesy. You gotta ask me nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE and JESSEP are frozen. Everyone'staring at Kaffee; The OFFICERS at their tables... KENDRICK... SAM...  MARKINSON... JO... KAFFEE makes his decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Jessep... if it's not too  much trouble, I'd like a copy of the  transfer order. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSEP smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD for a moment. JO's very disappointed. JESSEP stands there and watches the LAWYERS as they turn leave the Officer's Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I hate casualties, Matthew. There  are casualties even in victory. A  marine smothers a grenade and saves  his platoon, that marine's a hero.  The foundation of the unit, the fabric  of this base, the spirit of the Corps,  they are things worth fighting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARKINSON looks at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Dawson and Downey, they don't know  it, but they're smothering a grenade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARKINSON looks up as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a plane touches down on the runway. It's dusk in Washi and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little one-bedroom. Just the essential furniture, barel even that. KAFFEE's sitting and watching a baseball came on t.v. He' holding a copy of The Baseball Encyclopedia, normally his favorite reading material, but right now he's having trou keeping his mind in it. He's holding a baseball bat and  fiddling with it. The remnants of a pizza and Yoo-Hoo dinner sit next to hi His white uniform in a pile in the corner. There's a BUZZ the door. KAFFEE's not expecting anyone. He goes to the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE opens the door and JO walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've really missed you, Jo. I was  just saying to myself, "It's been  almost three hours since I last saw -- "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Markinson resigned his commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This afternoon. Sometime after we  left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to him in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already tried, I can't find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tried? Joanne, you're coming  dangerously close to the textbook  definition of interfering with a  government investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO hands KAFFEE the file she's been holding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Louden Downey's attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE's stunned. He opens the file and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Aunt Ginny. She said she feels like  she's known me for years. I suggested  that she might feel more comfortable  if I were directly involved with the  case. She had Louden sign the papers  about an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE looks up. Still too stunned to say anything. Then  finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it's way too much to hope  that you're just making this up to  bother me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'm not gonna make a  motion for separation, you're still  lead counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE hands her back the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Kendrick ordered the Code  Red. (beat) So do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON and DOWNEY come to attention as KAFFEE and JO are in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer on deck, ten hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE starts in immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Kendrick order the code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say sir like I just asked you  if you cleaned the latrine. You heard  what I said. Did Lt. Kendrick order  you guys to give Santiago a code  red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Downey) Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind telling me why the hell you  never mentioned this before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't ask us, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutie-pie shit's not gonna win you a  place in my heart, corporal, I get  paid no matter how much time you  spend in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I know you do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some understandable tension in the room, broken b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Let's sort this out. There  was a platoon meeting on August 6th  at four in the afternoon. And Lt.  Kendrick, he gave strict instructions  that nothing was to happen to  Santiago. Now is that true? I want  you to speak freely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, that's correct. But then he  dismissed the platoon and we all  went to our rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick came to our room, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About five minutes after the meeting  broke, sir. About 16:20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) And what happened then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick ordered us to give  Santiago a Code Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
