dialogues.text: ROSS is playing a game of full-court basketball with some other OFFICERS. A door at the far end of the court opens and KAFFEE and J walk in. They head down the sideline toward Ross. KAFFEE shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But ROSS is into the game...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Jack!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving him off) Hang on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were given an order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS stops cold and looks over at Kaffee. The game flies him. He motions to the locker room door in the corner of gym and the three of them make their way to privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you known about the  order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't -- (to KAFFEE) Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jo Galloway she's Downey's  lawyer. She's very pleased to meet  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly are you accusing me of,  commander?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm accusing you of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: and KAFFEE slams the door shut behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack didn't know about the order.  Because if he did and he hadn't told  us, Jack knows he'd be violating  about 14 articles of the code of  ethics. As it is, he's got enough to  worry about. God forbid our clients  decide to plead not guilty and testify  for the record that they were given  an order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kendrick specifically told the men  not to touch Santiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. And then he went into  Dawson and Downey's room and  specifically told them to give him a  code red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what Kendrick said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kendrick's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have proof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the defendants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I have 23 marines who aren't  accused of murder and a lieutenant  with four letters of commendation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did Markinson resign his  commission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I can subpoena  Markinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can try, but you won't find him.   You know what Markinson did for the  first 17 of his 21 years in the corps?  Counter Intelligence. Markinson's  gone. There is no Markinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the wind has been taken Out of Kaffee's sails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Jessep's star is on the rise.  Division'll give me a lot of room to  spare Jessep and the corps any  embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll knock it all down to assault.  Two years. They're home in six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No deal, we're going to a jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you'll lose, and Danny knows  it. And he knows that if we go to  court, I'll have to go all the way,  they'll be charged with the whole  truckload. Murder, Conspiracy, Conduct  Unbecoming, and even though he's got  me by the balls out here, Dan knows  that in a courtroom, he loses this  case. Danny's an awfully talented  lawyer, and he's not about to send  his clients go to jail for life when  he knows they could be home in six  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is now clear: Ross is as good as Kaffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's the end of this negotiation.  From this moment, we're on the record.  I'll see tomorrow morning at the  arraignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS turns and heads back to the gym as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaffee and JO are sitting at a table. Dawson and Downey a at parade rest. Kaffee lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the story: The Goverment's  offering Assault and Conduct  Unbecoming. Two years. You'll be  home in six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON and DOWNEY say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) "Wow, Kaffee, you're the greatest  lawyer in the world. How can we ever  thank you?" Fellas, you hear what I  just said, you're going home in six  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we can't do that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a deal, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did nothing wrong, sir. We did  our job. If that has consequences,  then I accept them. But'I won't say  I'm guilty, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE can't believe this. He looks over at JO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you -- (to DAWSON and DOWNEY) Did she put you up to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a code, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well zippity-doo-dah. You and your  code plead not guilty and you'll be  in jail for the rest of your life.  Do what I'm telling you and you'll  be home in six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do it, Harold. Six months. It's  nothing. It's a hockey season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permission to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do then, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After six months. We'd be dishonorably  discharged, right sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do then, sir? We joined  the corps 'cause we wanted to live  our lives by a certain code. And we  found it in the corps. And now you're  asking us to sign a piece of paper  that says we have no honor. You're  asking us to say we're not marines.  If a judge and jury decide that what  we did was wrong, I'll accept whatever  punishment they give. But I believe  I was riqht, sir. I believe I did my  job. And I won't dishonor myself, my  unit, or the Corps, so that I can qo  home in six months. (beat) Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON the four of them for a moment, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, I want to talk to corporal  Dawson alone for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo waits Just a moment before she calls out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Downey) Let's go in another room. Louden,  everything's gonna be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The M.P. has shown up and unlocked the cell door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to M.P.) We're gonna go into a holding room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, aye, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO, DOWNEY, and the M.P. are gone. KAFFEE paces a moment  before he says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like me that much, do you? (beat) Forget it, don't answer that, it  doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE paces another moment, then sits on the cot. He's t to choose his tack carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know, Downey worships you. He's  gonna do whatever you do. Are you  really gonna let this happen to him  because of a code? Harold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we were right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we were right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I think you'd lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You're such a coward, I can't believe  they let you wear a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE stares at DAWSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna feel responsible for  this, Harold. I did everything I  could. You're going to Levenworth  for the better part of your life,  and you know what? I don't give a  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE calls out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) M.P.!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE and DAWSON are staring each other down. The M.P. s up and unlocks the cell door. KAFFEE steps out to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What happened to saluting an officer  when he leaves the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON holds on KAFFEE. Then DAWSON, a man who would rath die than breach military protocol, takes his hands and pu them in his pockets. The cell door closes and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One light is on at the end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM has joined KAFFEE and JO. The mood is somber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson's gonna go to jail just to  spite me. Fine. If he wants to jump  off a cliff, that's his business.  I'm not gonna hold his hand on the  way down. (to SAM) I want to get him a new lawyer. How  do I do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just make a motion tomorrow  morning at the arraignment. The  judge'll ask you if you want to enter  a plea. You tell him you want new  counsel assigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Then that's that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Yeah. One thing, though. When you  ask the judge for new counsel, Danny,  be sure and ask nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to let 'em be judged! I  want you to stand up and make an  argument!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An argument that didn't work for  Calley at My Lai, an argument that  didn't work for the Nazis at  Nuremberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ sake, Sam, do you really  think that's the same as two teenage  marines executing a routine order  that they never believed would result  in harm? These guys aren't the Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a pause in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look now, Danny, but you're  making an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah. (beat) Tomorrow morning I'll get them a new  attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so afraid to be a lawyer?  Were daddy's expectations really  that high?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, spare me the psycho-babble  father bullshit. Dawson and Downey'll  have their day in court, but they'll  have it with another lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another lawyer won't be good enough.  They need you. You know how to win. (beat) You know they have a case. And you  know how to win. You walk away from  this now, and you have sealed their  fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their fate was sealed the moment  Santiago died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe they have a defense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Dawson both live in the same  dreamland. It doesn't matter what I  believe, it only matters what I can  prove. So please don't tell me what  I know and don't know. I know the  law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO looks at him, shakes her head, and turns to walk away. She turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know nothing about the law. You're  a used car salesman, Daniel. You're  an ambulance chaser with a rank.  You're nothing. (beat) Live with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo walks off leaving KAFFEE alone. We HOLD on KAFFEE. He' not having a good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE sits at the bar. The place is crowded with YUPPIES and STUDENTS. KAFFEE's been drinking there a while now. N to him is a YUPPIE LAWYER, regaling his FRIENDS with the  story of his latest brilliant maneuver in the world of hi stakes corporate law. We HOLD on a KAFFEE a moment longer, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So I told duncan if we leverage  the acquisition of Biotech, the  interrogatories would be there on  demand. All I have to do is not pick  up the phone and it'll run Flaherty  ten thousand a day in court costs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE sits on a bench in the night. He takes a sip from bottle he's holding in a brown paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright, sunny morning. The BAND is performing for a gro of day campers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON and DOWNEY are at the defense table, ROSS is his p KAFFEE walks in and joins JO and SAM at their table. Pape are being passed back and forth between ROSS and the SERG AT AMS. Quiet activity. The door in the back of the courtroom opens and RANDOLPH, marine colonel, enters and takes his place at the bench. can HEAR the band in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone present in the courtroom stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Docket number 411275. VR-5. United  States versus Lance Corporal Harold  W. Dawson and Private First Class  Loudon Downey. Defendants are charged  with Conspiracy to Commit Murder,  Murder in the First Degree, and  Conduct Unbecoming a United States  Marine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does defense wish to enter a plea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (pause) They're not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO, SAM, ROSS, RANDOLPH... it's hard to say who's the mos surprised. It takes everything Jo's got to suppress a smi The silence is broken by ROSS, who takes the two files, d them into his briefcase, closes the lid, and snaps it shu RANDOLPH looks at KAFFEE and ROSS, then turns to the SERG AT ARMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter a plea of not guilty for the  defendants. We'll adjourn until ten-  hundred, three weeks from today, at  which time this Court will reconvene  as a General Court-Martial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raps the gavel. RANDOLPH walks out. ROSS walks up the aisle without a wor to anyone. The M.P.'s come to escort DAWSON and DOWNEY ba to their cell. KAFFEE and JO and SAM are the only ones remaining. SAM is looking at KAFFEE with question marks in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does a junior grade with six  months experience and a track record  for plea bargaining get assigned a  murder case? (beat) Would it be so that it never sees  the inside of a courtroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE picks up his briefcase and begins heading toward t door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) We'll work out of my apartment.   Every night, seven o'clock. Jo, before  you come over tonight, pick up a  carton of legal pads, a half-dozen  boxes of red pens, a half-dozen boxes  of black pens. Sam get a couple of  desk lamps. I need you to start on a  preliminary medical profile and Jo,  we need all the fitness reports on  Dawson, Downey and Santiago. The  only thing I have to eat is Yoo-Hoo  and SugarSnacks, so if you want  anything else, bring it with you.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo's still stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE's at the door, stops, turns around, and takes it a in for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is what a courtroom looks  like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out the door, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the stuff, is a blackboard that's been hung on the  wall. Written across the top are three headings:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is on the floor, sorting papers into piles. KAFFEE co in from the kitchen with a fresh bottle of Yoo-Hoo and jo Sam on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you able to speak to your friend  at NIS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said if Markinson doesn't want  to be found, we're not gonna find  him. She said I could be Markinson  and you wouldn't know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Markinson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not Markinson, that's two  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM doesn't laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I was wondering, now that Joanne's  working on this... I was wondering  if you still need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) They were following an order, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An illegal order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Dawson and Downey know it  was an illegal order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter if they know, any  decent human being would've refused  to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not permitted to question  orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's the secret? What are the  magic words? I give orders every  day, and nobody follows them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have softball games and marching  bands. They work at a place where  you have to wear camouflage or you  might get shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam looks away. He doesn't buy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; pause) I need you. You're better at research  than I am and you know how to prepare  a witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo lets herself in. She's carrying a huge stack of papers under one arm, and a large brown paper bag under the othe But we stay with KAFFEE and Sam a moment longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got medical reports and Chinese  food. I say we eat first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE's still looking at SAM. SAM nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get any dumplings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remnants of the Chinese food is spread around. SAM an JO are sitting and taking notes from KAFFEE. As he speaks he'll pace slowly around, carrying his baseball bat. He r to the blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our defense. Intent: No one  can prove there was poison on the  raq. Code Red: They're common and  accepted in Guantanamo Bay. The Order: (he writes) A) Kendrick gave it. B) They had no  choice but to follow it. (beat) That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about motive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a little weak on motive. They  had one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because a person has a motive  doesn't mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax. We'll deal with the fenceline  shooting when it comes up. For now  we start here -- (pointing to INTENT) I don't know what made Santiago die,  I don't want to know. I just want to  be able to show it could've been  something other than poison. Jo,  talk to doctors. Find out everything  there is to know about lactic  acidosis. Let's start prepping for  Stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as we're on the subject of  the doctor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, three o'clock he doesn't  know what killed Santiago, then he  meets with Jessep, and at five o'clock  he says it was poison? The doctor's  covering up the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's a relief. I was afraid I  wouldn't be able to use the "Liar,  Liar, Pants on Fire" defense. We  can't prove coercion!! Alright,  fitness reports and biographical  information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cartons 3 and 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE looks at the cartons and the mind-numbing amount o paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Cliff-Notes on these things?

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SCENES
dialogues.text: The scenes cover the three weeks of preparation leading u to the trial, and are interspersed with shots of Kaffee's apartment getting messier, KAFFEE, JO and SAM flipping th documents and reference books, writing on the blackboard, dozzing off... We start with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo's on the phone, KAFFEE and SAM are going over testimon with SAM sitting in a mock witness chair. During this, KA will go to the door, pay the PIZZA Man for the pizza, and return without missing a single beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Captain Hill, this is Lt. Commander  Galloway, I'm an internal affairs  officer with the JAG Corps in  Washington, D.C. I'm trying to track  down a Captain Matthew Andrew  Markinson, USMC...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, other than the rope marks,  was there any other sign of external  damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No scrapes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) He resigned his commission a week  ago Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruises? Broken bones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No, please don't put me on hold --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, was there any sign of  violence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You mean other than the dead body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!! I walk into that every goddam  time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask the last question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOS -- JO pulls two thick volumes off a shelf and takes t to the table where SAM and KAFFEE are working. She plops books down where they join a pile of about two-dozen just like them and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LAWYERS have their books and papers spread out in fro of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick, the type of disciplinary  action, or "training'' as you say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please the Court, I maintain that  nothing could be more relevant than  what the defendants learned by the  example of, among others, the witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOS -- KAFFEE's paying the pizza boy again. He goes into living room where SAM is on the "stand". It's getting har to see the floor from all the papers, cartons, books, piz boxes, etc., and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HOLDING ROOM where DAWSON and DOWNEY are being put thro their paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened after Kendrick  came into your room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) He ordered me and Corporal Dawson to  give Willy a Code Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jo) His answers still have to come faster,  Jo. The Iowa farmboy thing'll play  for a while, but in the end it looks  like he's searching for the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dawson & Downey) He's right, and from now on, "Willy"  is Private Santiago. You start calling  him Willy and all of a sudden he's a  person who's got a mother who's gonna  miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOS -- The clock reads 3:37, and KAFFEE, in sweatpants an bathrobe, is pacing around slowly with his baseball bat a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM and JO art listening to a lecture for the 14th time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker faces. Don't flinch in front  of the jury. Something doesn't go  our way, don't hang your head, don't  shift in your seat, don't scribble  furiously. Whatever happens, you  have to look like it's exactly what  you knew was gonna happen. When you  pass me documents --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it swiftly, but don't look  overanxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) And don't wear that perfume in Court,  it wrecks my concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was talking to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to go home. Try to get some  sleep tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SAM) I'll give you a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM begins to gather up his things. He stands in front of KAFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SAM) You're a good man, Charlie Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam steps out the door. JO looks at the ground, then up a KAFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're gonna say. You  don't have to. We've had our  differences. I've said some things I  didn't mean, you've said some things  you didn't means but you're happy  that I stuck with the case. And if  you've gained a certain respect for  me over the last three weeks that  you didn't have before, well, of  course I'm happy about that, but we  don't have to make a whole big deal  out of it. You like me. I won't make  you say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just gonna tell you to wear  matching socks tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Oh. (beat) Okay. Good tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo walks out the door and KAFFEE closes it and locks it b her. Then he says, very softly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) We're gonna get creamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few M.P.Is are standing by the entrance. KAFFEE comes a the corner and heads toward the courtroom. We're immediat stricken by something: In his dress blue uniform he could easily be mistaken for real live naval officer. He opens the courtroom doors and walks into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few more M.P.'s are standing around. THE JURORS, nine  enlisted navy and marine men and women, are in their plac Ross is at his table looking through some papers, and DAW and DOWNEY, in handcuffs, are seated at the defense table The trial in a few moments from being underway and a few  people are milling about. KAFFEE walks down the aisle but stopped by a voice behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Kaffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE turns around to see a MAN and WOMAN who are clearl Dawson's parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna save our son, aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE continues on and stops next to JO, who's talking w a WOMAN in her mid-30's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, I want you to meet Ginny  Miller, Louden's aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Aunt Ginny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I was expecting someone   older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite the words of inspiration KAFFEE was hoping to h before he does the hardest thing he's ever had to do. He walks over to ROSS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last chance. I'll flip you for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDOLPH enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE walks back to his table as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All those having business with this  general court-martial, stand forward  and you shall be heard. Captain Julius  Alexander Randolph is presiding. God  save the United States of America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDOLPH raps the gavel. RANDOLPH without objection, the sworn confessions of the defendants have been read to the jury and entered into th court record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No objection, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No objection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the Government prepared to make  an opening statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS walks to the jury box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) The facts of the case are this: At  midnight on August 6th, the defendants  went into the barracks room of their  platoon-mate, PFC William Santiago.   They woke him up, tied his arms and  legs with rope, and forced a rag  into his throat. A few minutes later,  a chemical reaction in Santiago's  body called lactic acidosis caused  his lungs to begin bleeding. He  drowned in his own blood and was  pronounced dead at 32 minutes past  midnight. These are the facts of the  case. And they are undisputed. That's  right. The story I just told you is  the exact same story you're going to  hear from Corporal Dawson, and it's  the exact same story you're going to  hear from Private Downey. Furthermore,  the Government will also demonstrate  that the defendants soaked the rag  with poison, and entered Santiago's  room with motive and intent to kill. (beat) Now, Lt. Kaffee, is gonna try to  pull off a little magic act, he's  gonna try a little misdirection.  He's going to astonish you with  stories of rituals and dazzle you  with official sounding terms like  Code Red. He might even cut into a  few officers for you. He'll have no  evidence, mind you, none. But it's  gonna be entertaining. When we get  to the end, all the magic in the  world will not have been able to  divert your attention from the fact  that Willy Santiago is dead, and  Dawson and Downey killed him. These  are the facts of the case. (beat) And they are undisputed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS walks back to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kaffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before KAFFEE's even stood up, these words are coming out his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no poison on the rag and  there was no intent to kill and any  attempt to prove otherwise is futile  because it just ain't true. (beat) When Dawson and Downey went into  Santiago's room that night, it wasn't  because of vengeance or hatred, it  wasn't to kill or harm, and it wasn't  because they were looking for kicks  on a Friday night. It's because it  was what they were ordered to do. (beat) Let me say that again: It's because  it was what they were ordered to do.  Now, out in the real world, that  means nothing. And here at the  Washington Navy Yard, it doesn't  mean a whole lot more. But if you're  a marine assigned to Rifle Security  Company Windward, Guantanamo Bay,  Cuba, and you're given an order, you  follow it or you pack your bags. (beat) Make no mistake about it, Harold  Dawson and Louden Downey are sitting  before you in judgement today because  they did their job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE walks back to the table and takes his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the Government ready to call its  first witness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please the Court, the Government  calls Mr. R.C McGuire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While McCGUIRE, a civilian in his late 30's, is being swo in, KAFFEE has sat back down. He leans over to DAWSON and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWSON doesn't change his expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McGuire, would you state your  full name and occupation for the  record, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert C. McGuire, Special Agent,  Naval Investigative Service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McGuire, did your office receive  a letter from PFC William Santiago  on 3 August of this year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the letter say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a member of Private Santiago's  unit had illegally fired his weapon  over the fenceline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that marine identified in the  letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. I notified the barracks C.O.,  Colonel Jessep, that I would be coming  down to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did you find?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the shift reported, only one  sentry returned his weapon to the  switch with a round of ammunition  missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance Corporal Harold Dawson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to KAFFEE) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS goes back to his table. KAFFEE stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McGuire, have you questioned  Corporal Dawson about the fenceline  shooting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He claims to have been engaged  in some manner by the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my place --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Dawson's been charged with  a number of crimes, why wasn't he  charged with firing at the enemy  without cause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't enough evidence to  support such a charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McGuire, I don't understand what  you mean when you say there wasn't  enough evidence to support such a  charge. You had Willy Santiago's  letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago was the only witness, but I  never had a chance to interview him.  So I don't know what he saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we won't ever know, will we,  Mr. McGuire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAMMAKER, a young marine corporal, is being sworn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Carl Edward Hammaker, Marine  Barracks, Rifle Security Company  Windward, Second Platoon Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal, were you present at a  meeting that Lt. Kendrick held on  the afternoon of August 6th with the  members of second platoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you tell the Court the substance  of that meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick told us that we had an  informer in our group.  That Private  Santiago had gone outside the chain  of command and reported to the NIS  on a member of our platoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did that make you mad? (pause) You can tell the truth, corporal,  it's alright. Did it make you mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private Santiago betrayed a code  that we believe in very deeply, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were the other members of the squad  angry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Object --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were Dawson and Downey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please the Court, is the judge  advocate honestly asking this witness  to testify as to how the defendant  felt on August 6th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal, did Lt. Kendrick leave a  standing order at that meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it was clear that he didn't  want us to take matters into our own  hands, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, he said that Santiago wasn't to  be touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to KAFFEE) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Hammaker, were you in Dawson  and Downey's barracks room ten minutes  after this meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, I have no more questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAMMAKER gets off the stand, and KAFFEE watches while wal past DAWSON and DOWNEY. A barely perceptible exchange occ between the eyes of DAWSON and HAMMAKER. KAFFEE makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Government calls Corporal Raymond  Thomas --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please the Court, I understand Lt.   Ross is planning on calling all the  other members of Rifle Security  Company Windward to testify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In light of the defense that Lt.   Kaffee is planning to mount, the  explicit instructions of the platoon  leader seems particularly relevant  testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The defense is willing to concede  that all 23 witnesses will testify  substantially as Corporal Hammaker  did, if the Government is willing to  concede that none of them were in  Dawson and Downey's room at 16:20 on  August 6th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ROSS) Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Government'll agree to the  stipulation, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll adjourn for the day. You  can call your next witness in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PARADE GROUNDS - EARLY MORNING, two SAILORS are raisi the flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COMMANDER STONE, a Navy doctor in his mid-40's, is on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And he was pronounced dead at  zero-zero-thirty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Stone, what's lactic acidosis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the muscles and other cells of  the body burn sugar instead of oxygen,  lactic acid is produced. That lactic  acid is what caused Santiago's lungs  to bleed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does it take for the muscles  and other cells to begin burning  oxygen instead of sugar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty to thirty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what caused Santiago's muscles  and other cells to start burning  sugar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ingested poison of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, we object at this point.  The witness is speculating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander Stone is an expert medical  witness, in this courtroom his opinion  isn't considered speculation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander Stone is an internist, not  a criminologist, and the medical  facts here are ultimately  inconclusive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A point which I'm confident you'll  illustrate to the jury under cross-  examination, so I'm sure you won't  mind if his opinion is admitted now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, sir. Objection withdrawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Stone, did Willy Santiago die  of poisoning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you aware that the lab report  and the coroners report showed no  traces of poison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you justify --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are literally dozens of toxins  which are virtually undetectable,  both in the human body and on a  fabric. The nature of the acidosis  is the compelling factor in this  issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, you testified that it  takes lactic acidosis 20 to 30 minutes  before it becomes lethal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you, is it possible for a  person to have an affliction, some  sort of condition, which might, in  the case of this person, actually  speed up the process of acidosis  dramatically?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STONE says nothing for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Commander, is it possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What might some of those conditions  be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) If a person had a coronary disorder...  or a cerebral disorder, the process  would be more rapid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, if I had a coronary  condition, and a perfectly clean rag  was placed in my mouth, and the rag  was accidentally pushed too far down,  is it possible that my cells would  continue burning sugar after the rag  was taken out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would have to be a very serious  condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible to have a serious  coronary condition, where the initial  warning signals were so mild as to  escape a physician during a routine  medical exam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly. There would still be  symptoms though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of symptoms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are hundreds of symptoms of a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chest pains?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortness of breath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatigue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE has gone back to his table where JO has handed him some documents. He shows then to STONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, is this your signature?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This in an order for Private Santiago  to be put on restricted duty. Would  you read your hand written remarks  at the bottom of the page, please,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Initial testing negative. Patient  complains of chest pains, shortness  of breath, and fatigue. Restricted  from running distances over five  miles for one week."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, isn't it possible that  Santiago had a serious coronary  condition, and it was that condition,  and not some mysterious poison, that  caused the accelerated chemical  reaction?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I personally give the men a  physical examination every three  months. And every three months Private  Santiago got a clean bill of health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's why it had to be, poison,  right, Commander? 'Cause Lord knows,  if you put a man with a serious  coronary condition back on duty with  a clean bill of health, and that man  died from a heart related incident,  you'd have a lot to answer for,  wouldn't you, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Object. Move to strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained. Strike it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more questions, judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS stands immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Stone, you've held a license to  practice medicine for 21 years, you  are Board Certified in Internal  Medicine, you are the Chief of  Internal Medicine at a hospital which  serves over 8000 men. In your  professional opinion, was Willy  Santiago poisoned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, we re-new our objection  to Commander Stone's testimony, and  ask that it be stricken from the  record. And we further ask that the  Court instruct the jury to lend no  weight to this witness's testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE and SAM are dying, but they're trying to keep thei poker-faces. RANDOLPH'S gonna try to be polite about this but he thought he made himself clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The objection's overruled, counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the defense strenuously objects  and requests a meeting in chambers  so that his honor might have an  opportunity to hear discussion before  ruling on the objection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The objection of the defense has  been heard and overruled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noted. The witness is an expert and  the court will hear his opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, in your expert, professional  opinion, was Willy Santiago poisoned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir, I have no more  questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, you may step down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please the Court, while we reserve  the right to call rebuttal witnesses  if the need arises, the Government  rests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll stand in recess until ten- hundred hours this Monday, the l9th  at which time the defense will call  it's first witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDOLPH raps his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the courtroom begins clearing out. KAFFEE, JO and SAM are packing up their various papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I strenuously object? Is that how it  works? Objection. Overruled. No, no,  no, no, I strenuously object. Oh,  well if you strenuously object, let  me take a moment to reconsider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it on the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You also got it in the jury's head  that we're afraid of the doctor. You  object once so they can hear you say  he's not a criminologist. You keep  after it and it looks like this great  cross we did was just a bunch of  fancy lawyer tricks. It's the  difference between paper law and  trial --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, you even had the Judge saying  Stone was an expert!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, she made a mistake. Let's not  relive it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go call my wife. I'll meet  you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam starts to leave. JO turns and says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you hate them so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam stops and turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They beat up on a weakling, and that's  all they did. The rest is just  smokefilled coffee-house crap. They  tortured and tormented a weaker kid.  They didn't like him. And they killed  him. And why? Because he couldn't  run very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long silence. KAFFEE makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Everybody take the night  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I apologize, I, --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. We've been working 20  hour days for three and a half weeks  straight. Take the night off. Go see  your wife, see your daughter. Jo, do  whatever it is you do when you're  not here. What day is tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll start at ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE picks up his stuff and walks out. SAM and JO stand there uncomfortably for a moment. JO beg packing up her things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you like them so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) 'Cause they stand on a wall. (beat) And they say "Nothing's gonna hurt  you tonight. Not on my watch."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite their differences, SAM likes this woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the doctor. This  trial starts Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baseball game is on. KAFFEE's pacing slowly around, carrying his baseball bat. He's looking at the blackboard as he walks around the roo He's studying it. Studying it hard. There's a knock on th door. KAFFEE answers it. JO is standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to bother you, I should've  called first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was just watching a baseball  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering if -- how you'd feel  about my taking you to dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, are you asking me out on a date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounded like you were asking me  out on a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been asked out on dates before,  and that's what it sounded like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like seafood? I know a good  seafood place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the Virginia side of the Potomac. KAFFEE and JO are si at a table, finishing up dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My third case was a Drunk and  Disorderly. The trial lasted nine  weeks. I rounded up 31 people who  were in the bar that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine weeks on a D and D? What was  the prosecutor offering?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Well, you sure hustled the shit outta  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that, they moved me to internal  affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough to blame them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where I've earned two distinguished  service medals and two letters of  commendation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you always giving me your  resume?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I want you to think I'm good  lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't. (beat) I think you're an exceptional lawyer.  I watch the jurors, they respond to  you, they like you. I see you  convincing them. I think Dawson and  Downey are gonna end up owing their  lives to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Jo... I think you have to prepare  yourself for the fact that we're  gonna lose. (beat) Ross's opening speech, it was all  true. (beat) I mean, let's pretend for a minute  that it would actually matter to  this jury that the guys were given  an order. We can't prove it ever  happened. (beat) We'll keep doing what we're doing,  and we'll put on a show, but at the  end of the day, all we have is the  testimony of two people accused of  murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find Markinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, we're gonna lose. And we're gonna  lose huge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HOLD on then for a moment, and in VOICE OVER hear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Jeffrey Owen Howard, Marine  Barracks Windward, Guantanamo Bay,  Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CORPORAL HOWARD, the young marine who drove the lawyers a Cuba, is on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Howard, name some reasons  why a marine would get a code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being late for platoon or company  meetings, keeping his barracks in  disorder, falling back on a run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever received a code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. We were doing seven man  assault drills, and my weapon slipped.  It's just cause it was over a hundred  degrees and my palms were sweaty and  I'd forgot to use the resin like we  were taught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night the guys in my squad threw  a blanket over me and took turns  punching me in the arm for five  minutes. Then they poured glue on my  hands. And it worked, too, 'cause I  ain't never dropped my weapon since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was Private Santiago ever late for  platoon meetings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was his barracks ever in disorder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he ever fall back on a run?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he ever, prior to the night of  August 6th, receive a code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a code red 'cause your palms  were sweaty. Why didn't Santiago,  this burden to his unit, ever get  one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson wouldn't allow it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawson wouldn't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys talked tough about Santiago,  but they wouldn't go near him. They  were too afraid of Dawson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Object. The witness is characterizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll rephrase. Jeffrey, did you ever  want to give Santiago a code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause Dawson'd kick my butt, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good enough. Lt. Ross is gonna ask  you some questions now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS takes three books out of his briefcase and puts them the table. He brings one to HOWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Howard, I hold here The  Marine Guide and General Information  Handbook for New Recruits. Are you  familiar with this book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (hands him the book) Would you turn to the chapter that  deals with code reds, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just flip to the page in that book  that discusses code reds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you see, Code Red is a term we  use -- it's just used down at GITMO,  sir. I don't know if it actually --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS has produced another book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in luck, then. The Marine Corps  Guide for Sentry Duty, NAVY BASE  Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. I assume we'll  find the term code red and its  definition in this book, am I correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Corporal Howard, I'm a marine.  Is their no book, no manual or  pamphlet, no set of orders or  regulations that let me know that,  as a marine, one of my duties is to  perform code reds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) No sir. No books, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS sits. KAFFEE walks over to ROSS's table and picks up one of the books. He brings it to HOWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal, would you turn to the page  in this book that says where the  enlisted men's mess hall is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kaffee, that's not in the book,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, how did you know  where the enlisted men's mess hall  was if it's not in this book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I just followed the crowd at  chow time, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE chucks the book back on ROSS's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Howard, you can step down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (greatly relieved) Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE gives HOWARD a subtle "You Did Good, Kid" look, an we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the day's session. KAFFEE walks down the  hall with SAM and JO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven tonight, we'll do a final  Kendrick review. I want to slam-  dunk this guy.

dialogues.speaker: KAFFEE'S CAR
dialogues.text: as it drives along a street in the D.C. business district it's evening now and the windshield wipers are fighting  against a rain KAFFEE pulls over at his usual newsstand. hops out, leaving the lights flashing and the door open, runs to the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Luther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral, how's the big case goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nose to the grindstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No flies on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rolling stone gathers no moss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well it ain't over til the fat  lady sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that the truth. Catch you  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets back in his car, tosses the newspaper on the pass seat, and turns on the ignition. And as soon as he does -- a hand is slapped over his mouth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Matthew Markinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and KAFFEE jumps out of his skin. Because sitting in the back seat, in civilian clothes, is MARKINSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus fucking Christ!!--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left the door unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared the shit outta me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you aware you're under subpoena?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm also aware that the lives  of two marines are in your hands. If  there was something I could do about  that, I would, but since I can't,  all I can do is help you. Why don't  you drive, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE begins driving down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it a code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Kendrick give the order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you witness it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't need to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you witness it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was never gonna be transferred  off the base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with this, KAFFEE screeches the car over to the side the road. He grabs the parking brake and pulls it up. He  turns to Markinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Jessep was going to keep him on the  base. He said he wanted him trained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got the transfer order. It's  got your signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I signed it the morning you  arrived in Cuba. Six days after  Santiago died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE's wheels are spinning. He's pumped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get you a deal. Some kind  of immunity with the prosecutor. In  about four days, you're gonna appear  as a witness for the defense, and  you're gonna tell the court exactly  what you told me. Right now I'm gonna  check you into a motel, and we're  gonna start from the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want a deal. And I don't  want immunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE shakes his head and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I want you to know, I'm proud neither  of what I've done nor what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE puts the car in gear and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where KAFFEE has just finished telling his story to an am SAM and JO. There's silence. Then JO has a total adrenaline rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Route 23 Best Western.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want him guarded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's probably a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) This is Lt. Commander Joanne Galloway.  My clearance code is 411273.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE is impressed. He turns to SAM --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearance code?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SAM) I don't have a clearance code. Do  you have a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) It's Jo Galloway. I need to secure a  witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo continues giving information to the person on the phon while Kaffee keeps talking to the both of them. Sam is wr down notes as fast as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He also said that Jessep's lying  about the transportation off the  base. Jessep said six the next morning  was the first flight Santiago could've  left on, Markinson says there was a  plane that left seven hours earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was impressive. Did you hear  what I just said about the flight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, when a plane takes off from a  base, there's gotta be some kind of  record kept, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need the Tower Chief's Log for  GITMO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SAM) Get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, don't get crazy about this. We  don't know who Markinson is. We don't  know what the log book's gonna say.  You just concentrate on Downey. I'm  gonna talk to Ross and tell him where  we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sing-song) "Kaffee's got his case now, Kaffee's  got his case now."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are like seven of the strangest  women I have ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS sets two drinks down in front of KAFFEE and RO who are sitting across from each other in a booth in the  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was nice work today. The redirect  on Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have Markinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS only takes a moment digest this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motel room in Arlington with 14  Federal Marshals outside his door.   Take a sip of your drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The transfer order that Parkinson  signed is phoney. And Jessep's  statement that the six a.m. flight  was the first available is a lie,  we're checking the tower chief's  log. But in the meantime I'm gonna  put the Apostle Jon Kendrick on the  stand and see if we can't have a  little fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS takes another sip of his drink, then lays it on the  line for Kaffee..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an obligation to tell you  that if you accuse Kendrick or Jessep  of any crime without proper evidence,  you'll be subject to Court-Martial  for professional misconduct. And  that's something that'll be stapled  to every job application you ever  fill out. Markinson's not gonna hold  up, he's a crazy man. I'm not saying  this to intimidate you. I'm being  your lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jack. And I wanna tell you  that I think the whole fuckin' bunch  of you are certifiably insane. And  this code of honor of yours makes me  wanna beat the shit outta something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare lump me in with Jessep  and Markinson and Kendrick because  we wear the same uniform. I'm your  friend, Danny, and I'm telling you,  I don't think your clients belong in  jail. But I don't get to make that  decision. I represent the Government  of the United States. Without passion  or prejudice. And my client has a  case. (pause) I want you to acknowledge that the  judge advocate has made you aware of  the possible consequences involved  in accusing a marine officer of a  felony without proper evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been so advised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS stands up and heaves a few dollars on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got bullied into that courtroom,  Danny. By everyone. By Dawson, by  Galloway, shit, I practically dared  you. Not for a second have you  believed you could win. You got  bullied into that room by the memory  of a dead lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) You're a lousy softball player, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boys are going down. I can't  stop it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are filing in. KENDRICK is standing at the entranc to the courtroom. KAFFEE glides past him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batter up, J.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KENDRICK watches this impudent thing walk into the courtr as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KENDRICK's on the stand. What drives Kaffee's entire  examination of Kendrick is this: Kaffee's got him. He's g win. At least this round. All he has to do is not let his emotions take control of his professional skill. SAM will have files and documents ready to hand Kaffee as needs them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick, in your opinion, was  Private Santiago a good marine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say he was about average.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, you signed three fitness  reports on Santiago. On all three  reports you indicated a rating of  Below Average.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Private Santiago was Below  Average I didn't see the need in  trampling on a man's grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We appreciate that, but you're under  oath now, and I think unpleasant as  it may be, we'd all just as soon  hear the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm aware of my oath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE's handed some more files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, these are the last three  fitness reports you signed for Lance  Corporal Dawson and PFC Downey. Downey  received three straight marks of  Exceptional. Dawson received two  marks of Exceptional, but on this  most recent report, dated June 9th  of this year, he received a rating  of Below Average. It's this last  report that I'd like to discuss for  a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance Corporal Dawson's ranking after  Infantry Training School was perfect.  Records indicate that over half that  class has since been promoted to  full corporal, while Dawson has  remained a lance corporal. Was  Dawson's promotion held up because  of this last fitness report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recall why Dawson was given  such a poor grade on this report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I don't. I have many men in  my charge, Lieutenant, I write many  fitness reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recall an incident involving  a PFC Curtis Barnes who'd been found  stealing liquor from the Officer's  Club?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you report private Barnes to the  proper authorities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have two books at my bedside,  Lieutenant, the Marine Code of Conduct  and the King James Bible. The only  proper authorities I'm aware of are  my Commanding Officer, Colonel Nathan  R. Jessep and the Lord our God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Kendrick, at your request, I can  have the record reflect your lack of  acknowledgment of this court as a  proper authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection. Argumentative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained. (to KAFFEE) Watch yourself, counselor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you report Private Barnes to  your superiors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember thinking very highly of  Private Barnes, and not wanting to  see his record tarnished by a formal  charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You preferred it to be handled within  the unit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I most certainly did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, do you know what a Code  Red is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever ordered a code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, did you order Dawson and  two other men to make sure that  Private Barnes receive no food or  drink except water for a period of  seven days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a distortion of the truth.  Private Barnes was placed on barracks  restriction. He was given water and  vitamin supplements, and I assure  you that at no time was his health  in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it was lovely for Private  Barnes, but you did order the barracks  restriction, didn't you? And you did  order the denial of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't this form of discipline be  considered a code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Not necessarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I called the other 8000 men at  Guantanamo Bay to testify, would  they consider it a Code Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please the court, the witness can't  possibly testify as to what 8000  other men would say. We object to  this entire line of questioning as  argumentative and irrelevant badgering  of the witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Government's objection is  sustained, Lt. Kaffee, and I would  remind you that you're now questioning  marine officer with an impeccable  service record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE looks over at DAWSON. They share a brief moment be KAFFEE turns back to KENDRICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, was Dawson given a rating  of Below Average on this last fitness  report because you learned held been  sneaking food to Private Barnes? (to ROSS) Not so fast. (to KENDRICK) Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Dawson was found to be Below  Average because he committed a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What crime did he commit? (beat) Lieutenant Kendrick? (beat) Dawson brought a hungry guy some  food. What crime did he commit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disobeyed an order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And because he did, because he  exercised his own set of values,  because he made a decision about the  welfare of a marine that was in  conflict with an order of yours, he  was punished, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal Dawson disobeyed an order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it wasn't a order, was it?  After all, it's peacetime. He wasn't  being asked to secure a hill... or  advance on a beachhead. I mean, surely  a marine of Dawson's intelligence  can be trusted to determine on his  own, which are the really important  orders, and which orders might, say,  be morally questionable. (beat) Lt. Kendrick? (beat) Can he? Can Corporal Dawson determine  on his own which orders he's gonna  follow? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he can not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lesson he learned after the Curtis  Barnes incident, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know so, don't you, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Object!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Kendrick, one final  question: if you ordered Dawson to  give Santiago a code red...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- please the court --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told those men not to touch  Santiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- is it reasonable to think that he  would've disobeyed you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, don't answer that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to, I'm through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS doesn't even wait before he says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Kendrick, did you order  Corporal Dawson and Private Downey  to give Willy Santiaga code red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But KENDRICK isn't listening -- he's glaring at Kaffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Lt. Kendrick, did you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FWAP! - a nerf ball slams into a hoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO and KAFFEE. KAFFEE's pumped and shooting baskets as Sa walks in with some bound papers under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the tower chief's log for  that night. Jessep was telling the  truth. The six a.m. flight was the  first plane out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE lets the ball drop out of his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SEDAN, with U.S. MARSHALL stenciled on the door, sits i front of one of the rooms, and the two FEDERAL AGENTS ins the car are reading the newspaper as KAFFEE'S CAR pulls n to them and KAFFEE jumps out. AGENT #1 sticks his head out the window and calls to KAFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workin' late, lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAFFEE pays no attention and bangs on MARKINSON's door. T door opens and KAFFEE walks into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
